fields.value: Emigrant Savings Bank Depositor Data: "Depositor Database," "Household Database," and "Transactions Database" Files Created by Anbinder, O Grada, and Wegge

dsDescriptionValue.value: This project involved creating a database of information on the predominantly Irish immigrants who opened the first 18,000 accounts at New York's Emigrant Savings Bank from 1850 to 1858. The "Depositor Database" contains a line for each of the bank's depositors and we supplemented the information in the bank's ledgers with data from the U.S. census, ship manifests, city directories, newspapers, death records, and court documents (including wills probated in the city's Surrogates Court). The "Household Database" contains a line for each household with accounts at the bank.  The "Transactions Database" records every deposit, withdrawal, and interest payment, with the date they took place, for 20% of the bank's first 18,000 accounts.

files.description: This version of the data has most everything a historian should need. It contains all information we know about each depositor’s residential, occupational, birthplace, and savings history.  It also has every piece of information we found about them in censuses, ship manifests, city directories, newspapers, and death records. It does not contain information about trustees and beneficiaries for trust accounts (for these accounts, the “beneficiary” is listed in our “depositor” column. The abridged database does not contain information about a depositor’s parents. Nor does it contain the names of a depositor’s siblings or the whereabouts of a depositor’s children. What data we have on those subjects can be found in the full depositor database.
files.label: Anbinder, O Grada, Wegge Abridged Depositor Database.xlsb

dataFile.filename: Anbinder, O Grada, Wegge Abridged Depositor Database.xlsb
dataFile.description: This version of the data has most everything a historian should need. It contains all information we know about each depositor’s residential, occupational, birthplace, and savings history.  It also has every piece of information we found about them in censuses, ship manifests, city directories, newspapers, and death records. It does not contain information about trustees and beneficiaries for trust accounts (for these accounts, the “beneficiary” is listed in our “depositor” column. The abridged database does not contain information about a depositor’s parents. Nor does it contain the names of a depositor’s siblings or the whereabouts of a depositor’s children. What data we have on those subjects can be found in the full depositor database.

files.description: This is the complete database listing all depositors who opened accounts from 1850 to 1858, their savings, and information we found about them from census and other documents.
files.label: Anbinder, O Grada, Wegge, Emigrant Savings Bank Full Depositor Database.xlsb

dataFile.filename: Anbinder, O Grada, Wegge, Emigrant Savings Bank Full Depositor Database.xlsb
dataFile.description: This is the complete database listing all depositors who opened accounts from 1850 to 1858, their savings, and information we found about them from census and other documents.

files.description: This database records every transaction made in a 20% sample of the first 18,000 accounts opened at the New York's Emigrant Savings Bank. These accounts were opened from 1850 to 1858. The hand-written deposit ledgers from which these transactions were transcribed were utilized by the bank until late 1869, when it began transitioning to new ledger books (a process which it did not complete until early 1870), but these newer ledgers are no longer extant.  As a result, this database records all transactions for these accounts from the date they were opened until either the account was closed or these ledger books were retired from use in the fall and winter of 1869-1870. The original ledger books are available in the Emigrant Savings Bank Records, Manuscripts and Archives Division, New York Public Library. They are also available online at https://search.ancestry.com/search/db.aspx?dbid=8760.
files.label: Anbinder, O Grada, Wegge, Emigrant Savings Bank Transactions Database .tab

dataFile.filename: Anbinder, O Grada, Wegge, Emigrant Savings Bank Transactions Database .tab
dataFile.description: This database records every transaction made in a 20% sample of the first 18,000 accounts opened at the New York's Emigrant Savings Bank. These accounts were opened from 1850 to 1858. The hand-written deposit ledgers from which these transactions were transcribed were utilized by the bank until late 1869, when it began transitioning to new ledger books (a process which it did not complete until early 1870), but these newer ledgers are no longer extant.  As a result, this database records all transactions for these accounts from the date they were opened until either the account was closed or these ledger books were retired from use in the fall and winter of 1869-1870. The original ledger books are available in the Emigrant Savings Bank Records, Manuscripts and Archives Division, New York Public Library. They are also available online at https://search.ancestry.com/search/db.aspx?dbid=8760.

files.description: For almost every question one might want to ask concerning the Emigrant Savings Bank depositors, the place to begin to seek answers is our Depositor Database.  The information in it concerning the depositors’ birthplaces, occupations, places of residence, etc., has gone through several more years of additions, fact checking, and editing than the information in this “Household Database.” The Household Database, therefore, has only two real uses.  First, it allows researchers to better understand how we arrived at the "peak household savings" figures listed in the Depositor Database. As we describe in the notes to that database, the peak savings amount we list for each depositor is not the savings of that person alone, but of all the people in his or her household. So, if Patrick Kelly had an account with $100 in it on January 1, 1855, and his wife Bridget had her own account with the same balance on the same date, and that total of $200 is the most they had in their accounts on any one day that their accounts were open, then we list each of them in the Depositor Database as having a peak household savings of $200. In some cases, adult children who lived with their parents had their own accounts and their savings was counted as part of the family’s household savings too so long as we believed that they were still living with their parents when the peak household balance was achieved. The Household Database lists which accounts were used to determine Patrick and Bridget Kelly’s household savings and who the other members of his household were who owned Emigrant Savings Bank accounts.
files.label: Anbinder, O Grada, Wegge, Household Database.xlsb

dataFile.filename: Anbinder, O Grada, Wegge, Household Database.xlsb
